dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Allen, D. 2013. Lepidocephalus macrochir. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description: The species is known from scattered records from the Malay Peninsula (e.g., the Pahang River near Mentakab, Malaysia), and Indonesia (Kalimantan (Kapuas River), eastern Sumatra (Lamatang and Enim rivers; Kottelat et al. 1993) and Java (Pepeh River, a tributary of the Solo River, Surakarta)). The identity of records from Thailand (central Thailand: Chao Phraya River; Nan River tributaries and Nakon Sawan) requires confirmation, however the species is present in Thai parts of the Malay Peninsula.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: This species can be easily diagnosed from Lepidocephalus spectrum by the presence of eyes and dark pigment on the body, and absence of tubules along the lateral line; from L. pahangensis by the presence of scales on top of the head; from L. pallens by having the dorsal-fin origin well behind (vs. over) the pelvic-fin origin (predorsal length 65.0-69.3 vs. 59.9% SL); and from L. nanensis by having a shorter snout (3.9-5.1 vs. 5.6-7.4% SL; 23.3-27.1 vs. 28.6-38.1% HL).  This species further differs from L. pahangensis in having 8 (vs. 9) branched dorsal-fin rays and 5-6 (vs. 4) branched anal-fin rays, and from L. pallens, L. pahangensis and L. spectrum in having a shorter head (16.6-18.8 vs. 23.2, 21.8, and 21.3-23.2% SL respectively) (Ref. 95334).

DD

Red List Criteria

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2013

Assessor/s
Allen, D.

Reviewer/s
Vidthayanon, C. & Smith, K.

Contributor/s

Justification
The species is known from a few scattered records across southeast Asia. Little is known of the species' habitats, ecology, or threats, and it is considered Data Deficient.
